t: "Deal not with us, they said, according to our wickedness, but according to thy mercy.
Simon made a covenant with them and fought them not. Howbeit, he cast them out of the city, and cleansed the houses wherein were the idols, and then he entered into it with hymns and blessings.
And he put all uncleanness out of it, and placed such men there as would keep the law, and made the city stronger than it was before, and built therein a dwellingplace for himself.

Now they that were in the citadel at Jerusalem were kept so strait, that they could neither come forth into the country, nor buy, nor sell; wherefore they were in great distress for want of victuals, and a great number of them perished through famine.
Then cried they unto Simon, beseeching him to be at one with them: which thing he granted them; and when he had put them out from thence, he cleansed the citadel from pollutions:

And entered into it the three and twentieth day of the second month in the hundred seventy and first year, with thanksgiving, and branches of palm trees, and with harps, and cymbals, and viols, and hymns, and songs: because there was destroyed a great enemy out of Israel.
He ordained also that that day should be kept every year with gladness. Moreover he strengthened the mountain of the temple by the citadel, and dwelt there himself, and his company.
And when Simon saw that John his son was a valiant man, he made him captain of all the hosts: and he dwelt in Gazara.
Now in the hundred seventy and second year king Demetrius gathered his forces together, and went into Media, to get him help to fight against Tryphon.
But when Arsaces, the king of Persia and Media, heard that Demetrius was entered within his borders, he sent one of his princes to take him alive:
Who went and discomfited the host of Demetrius, and took him, and brought him to Arsaces, by whom he was put in ward.
As for the land of Judea, that was quiet all the days of Simon; for he sought the good of his nation in every way: and his authority and his glory pleased them well all his days.
And beside all this he took Gazara, and Bethsura, and the citadel, and put all uncleanness out of them; there was none that did withstand him.
Then did they till their ground in peace, and the earth gave her increase, and the trees of the field did yield their fruit:
And he took Joppa for an haven, and made it an entrance to the isles of the sea.
He enlarged the bounds of his nation, and recovered the country,
And old men sat all in the streets, communing together of good things, and the young men put on glorious and warlike apparel.
He provided victuals for the cities, and set in them all manner of instruments of defence, so that his honourable name was renowned unto the end of the world.
He made peace in the land, and Israel rejoiced with great joy:
For every man sat under his vine and his fig tree, and there was none to vex them:
Yea, all the kings that were in the land were defeated, and he humbled all that were wicked workers of mischief.
He strengthened all those of his people that were brought low: the law he searched out;
And every contemner of the law and wicked person he took away.
He beautified the sanctuary, and multiplied vessels of honour.
When it was heard at Rome, and as far as Sparta, that Jonathan was dead, they were exceeding sorry.
But as soon as they heard that Simon his brother was made high priest in his stead, and ruled the country, and the cities therein:
They wrote unto him in tables of brass, to renew the friendship and league which they had made with Judas and Jonathan his brethren:
Which writings were read before the congregation at Jerusalem.

This is the copy of the letters that the Lacedemonians sent; The rulers of the Lacedemonians, with the city, unto Simon the high priest, and the elders, and priests, and residue of the people in Judea, our brethren, send greeting:
The ambassadors that are come unto us declare unto us what glory and honour ye have obtained: wherefore we were glad at their coming.

And therefore we have ordained that this be registered in the records of our people in way of memorial: Numenius the son of Antiochus, and Antipater the son of Jason, the Jews' ambassadors, are come unto us, to renew the friendship that we had with them.

Wherefore it pleaseth us well to renew the league with them, and to send unto them tables of brass, to be a testimony of the friendship and league that is between us: that their deputies might have them to shew unto you.
Wherefore now have we written unto you.
This is the copy of the letters that were sent unto Simon from the Romans; Quintus Memmius and Titus Manlius, ambassadors of the Romans, unto the people of the Jews send greeting:
Whatsoever Demetrius the king doth entreat of you, we have written unto him, according to your advice:
To send ambassadors unto us, that we may hear and determine the matter between them: for he is gone from our counsel.
Fare ye well.
In the hundred threescore and fourteenth year came Antiochus into the land of his fathers: at which time all the forces came together unto him, so that few were left with Tryphon.
Wherefore Antiochus pursued after him, and he fled unto Dora, which lieth by the sea side:
For he saw that troubles came upon him all at once, and that his forces had forsaken him.
Then encamped Antiochus against Dora, having with him an hundred and twenty thousand men of war, and eight thousand horsemen.
And when he had compassed the city round about, and joined ships close to the town on the sea side, he vexed it sore by land and by sea, neither suffered he any to go out or in.
Then came Numenius, and his company from Rome, having letters unto the kings and countries; wherein were written these things:
Lucius, consul of the Romans, unto king Ptolemee sendeth greeting:
The Jews' ambassadors, our friends and confederates, are come unto us, renewing their old friendship and league: being sent from Simon the high priest, and from the people of the Jews:
And have brought a shield of gold of a thousand pound.
We have thought good therefore to write unto you, that ye do them no hurt, nor war against them, their cities, or countries, lest any grief come unto us, as it is agreed between us:
Also that ye receive of them the shield of gold.
Furthermore, we have written unto Demetrius the king to take off those exactions which he demandeth of them.
Forasmuch as we are determined to aid them, that they may have no trouble.
Fare ye well.
The same things wrote we also unto king Demetrius, and Attalus, to Ariarathes, and Arsaces,
And to all the countries,

And to Lampsacus, and Strataceus, and unto Pergamus, and Miletus, and unto Chios, and Samos, and Metylene, and Lycia, and Rhodes, and Aradus, and Phaselis, and Cos, and Sidon, and Aradus, and Gortyna, and Cnidus, and Cyprus, and Cyrene.
And if these nations do any thing against the people of the Jews, we will take vengeance upon them, saith the Lord.
When Simon heard these things, he received them thankfully.
And determined to gather together a great number of men of war, and to subdue the country again.
Also he took Bethsura, and Gazara, and the citadel, out of which the enemies had been driven before.
And when he had fortified them, he set therein soldiers, and victuals.
Moreover he chose men and sent them to king Demetrius, to the end he should grant the land a release from all exactions;
For Tryphon did nothing but oppress the people.
Wherefore they complained unto him.
And the king sent unto Simon a great shield of gold of a thousand pound, and confirmed him governor of all the country.
But Tryphon dissembled with him, and dealt deceitfully against him, and went about to slay him.
Howbeit Simon perceived that he was setting a trap for him, and therefore was afraid of him, and came no more at all into his presence.
Then sent Tryphon soldiers, and horsemen, unto Gazara, to the end that they might destroy Simon:
But they of Gazara shut the gates, and made no answer at all to him.
Wherefore Tryphon removed his host, and went unto Judea, wasting the country, and spoiling the people of Bethsura:
But Simon followed after him, and pitched his host over against him.
Now when Tryphon saw that Simon was risen up instead of his brother Jonathan, and meant to join battle with him, he sent ambassadors unto him,
Saying, As for Jonathan thy brother, we have kept him back for money that he owed unto the king's treasury, and for other things that he had the doing of.
Howbeit now send an hundred talents of silver, and two of his sons for hostages, that when he is at liberty he may not revolt from us, and we will let him go.
Hereupon Simon, albeit that he perceived that they spake deceitfully unto him yet sent he the money and the children, lest peradventure he should procure to himself great hatred of the people:
Who might have said, Because I sent him not the money and the children, therefore is Jonathan dead.
So when he had received the money and the children, Tryphon broke his covenant, neither let Jonathan go.
And after this came Tryphon to invade the country, and destroy it, going round about by Adora:
But Simon and his host marched against him in every place, wheresoever he went.
Now they that were in the citadel sent messengers unto Tryphon, that he should come unto them quickly:
Unto whom he sent horsemen, and other soldiers, to the end he might relieve them:
But they fell into the hands of Simon, and he slew them every one.
And they wrote a copy of these letters unto Simon the high priest.
Now Antiochus was encamped against Dora, hard by the town: and his company with him continually vexed Tryphon, to hinder him from going out or coming in.
Then Simon sent unto him two thousand chosen men to fight for him: silver also, and gold, and much armour.
But he would not receive them, but frustrated all the covenants which he had made with him afore, and became strange unto him.
Furthermore he sent Athenobius, one of his friends, to commune with him, and say, Ye withhold Joppa, and Gazara, and the tower that is in Jerusalem, which are cities of my realm.
The borders thereof ye have wasted, and done great hurt in the land, and got the dominion of many places within my kingdom.
Now therefore deliver the cities which ye have taken, and the tributes of the places, whereof ye have gotten dominion without the borders of Judea:
Or else give me for them five hundred talents of silver; and for the harm that ye have done, and the tribute of the cities, other five hundred talents: or else we will come and fight against you.

So Athenobius the king's friend came to Jerusalem: and when he saw the glory of Simon, and the cupboard of gold and silver plate, and his great attendance, he was astonished, and told him the king's message.

Then answered Simon, and said unto him, We have neither taken other men's land, nor holden that which appertaineth to others, but the inheritance of our fathers, which our enemies had wrongfully in possession a certain time.
Wherefore we, having opportunity, hold the inheritance of our fathers.
And whereas thou demandest Joppa and Gazara, albeit they did great harm unto the people in our country, yet will we give an hundred talents for them. Hereunto Athenobius answered him not a word;
But returned back to the king in a rage, and made report unto him of Simon's glory, and of all that he had seen: wherefore the king was exceedingly wroth.
In the mean season Tryphon entered into a ship, and fled unto Orthosia.
Then the king made Cendebeus captain of the sea coast, and gave him an host of footmen and horsemen,
And commanded him to remove his army toward Judea, and to build up Kedron, and to fortify the gates, and to war against the people; but as for the king himself, he pursued after Tryphon.
So Cendebeus came to Jamnia, and began to provoke the people, and to invade Judea, and to take prisoners, and slay.
And he built up Kedron, and set horsemen there, and an host of footmen, to the end that issuing out they might make outroads upon the ways of Judea, as the king had commanded him.
Wherefore John went up from Gazara, and told Simon his father what Cendebeus had done.

Then Simon called his two eldest sons, Judas and John, and said unto them, I, and my brethren, and my father's house, have ever from my youth unto this day fought against the enemies of Israel; and things have prospered so well in our hands, that we have delivered Israel oftentimes.
